description: Microsoft Project 2013 is the latest offering by Microsoft into the software realm of PMIS (Project Management Information Systems).  This type of tool is used to help a project manager consolidate the number of tools they may use (e.g.  Calendar systems, email, contacts and some budgeting software and reporting software) into a single software tool for initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling and even closing a project.  Within a single tool, a project manager can manage a project’s triple constraints:  Cost, Scope and Time.  This series covers every exam objective to help a viewer to prepare for the Microsoft exam 74-343 —Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013.
name: Microsoft Project 2013 - 74-343
subtitle: Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013

episodes.description: Microsoft Project 2013 is the latest offering by Microsoft into the software realm of PMIS (Project Management Information Systems).  This type of tool is used to help a project manager consolidate the number of tools they may use (e.g.  Calendar systems, email, contacts and some budgeting software and reporting software) into a single software tool for initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling and even closing a project.  Within a single tool, a project manager can manage a project’s triple constraints:  Cost, Scope and Time.  This series covers every exam objective to help a viewer to prepare for the Microsoft exam 74-343 —Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013.
episodes.title: Microsoft Project
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.770
[SOUND] In this video,
we're gonna take a minute to talk

2
00:00:06.770 --> 00:00:12.501
about the Microsoft Project certification.

3
00:00:12.501 --> 00:00:14.960
In particular,
we will get a little detail here.

4
00:00:14.960 --> 00:00:19.835
The 74-343 exam which, for those of
you that are wanting to learn how to

5
00:00:19.835 --> 00:00:24.490
use the Microsoft Project software,
it really is a great place to start.

6
00:00:24.490 --> 00:00:27.590
You can jump right in, you can get
a great certification out of it.

7
00:00:27.590 --> 00:00:30.430
Once you've learned the material and
you've passed the exam,

8
00:00:30.430 --> 00:00:34.460
you get the Microsoft Certified
Professional, or MCP certification.

9
00:00:34.460 --> 00:00:37.030
So I mean, this is really a great thing.

10
00:00:37.030 --> 00:00:40.540
Not just for project managers, but anybody
who works in a project environment.

11
00:00:40.540 --> 00:00:44.710
To be able to learn the software and
get a certification at the same time.

12
00:00:44.710 --> 00:00:46.310
I really enjoy this one.

13
00:00:46.310 --> 00:00:49.790
>> Yeah, with Microsoft Project 2013,
we can actually go ahead and

14
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:51.630
take a look at their exam objectives.

15
00:00:51.630 --> 00:00:52.750
On my screen I went ahead and

16
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:56.130
pulled up the exam objectives
from Microsoft's site itself.

17
00:00:56.130 --> 00:00:58.820
And you can see that it gives you a lot
of information right here at the top,

18
00:00:58.820 --> 00:01:01.652
most importantly for me normally
is gonna be, of course, the cost.

19
00:01:01.652 --> 00:01:03.558
>> [LAUGH]
>> The cost has gone up a little

20
00:01:03.558 --> 00:01:04.750
bit over time.

21
00:01:04.750 --> 00:01:08.680
About $150, US dollars of course,
is what you can do.

22
00:01:08.680 --> 00:01:12.800
And if you have Microsoft Project 2013,
they have the certification for that.

23
00:01:12.800 --> 00:01:18.270
You may still see that there's still
Microsoft Project 2010 as a possibility,

24
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:20.570
but the older editions have
pretty much gone away,

25
00:01:20.570 --> 00:01:22.480
they've been deprecated at this point.

26
00:01:22.480 --> 00:01:23.910
So those exams will no longer count.

27
00:01:23.910 --> 00:01:25.152
But if you scroll down,

28
00:01:25.152 --> 00:01:28.709
from this point here you can actually
then see the skills measured.

29
00:01:28.709 --> 00:01:30.860
And this is what we
really wanna focus in on,

30
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:34.177
is to take a look at some of these
different exam objectives to help us

31
00:01:34.177 --> 00:01:37.540
to be able to understand what
they're gonna ask us about.

32
00:01:37.540 --> 00:01:40.700
As well as to help us did it to
figure out how a project actually

33
00:01:40.700 --> 00:01:43.860
works in the betterment of
actually doing project management.

34
00:01:43.860 --> 00:01:46.870
So, the first field that we're
actually taking a look at in the exam

35
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:49.980
objectives here is going to
be initializing a project.

36
00:01:49.980 --> 00:01:53.430
Now a project really wants you to actually
know how to get a project that you've

37
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:57.510
already got all the information for
and get started as soon as you can.

38
00:01:57.510 --> 00:01:59.280
So in that project initialization,

39
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:02.510
we're going to talk about things
like just how do we actually get

40
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:05.980
the project started in order to show
some of the different ways to do so.

41
00:02:05.980 --> 00:02:09.920
And the basic information that we
need just so that we can begin.

42
00:02:09.920 --> 00:02:10.560
>> Yeah, and I

43
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:12.860
really like the way Microsoft's
arranged the objectives on this one.

44
00:02:12.860 --> 00:02:15.730
Because you'll notice where it starts
with is just creating a blank project.

45
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:19.170
They're not expecting you to have any
prior knowledge of Microsoft Project,

46
00:02:19.170 --> 00:02:22.180
you don't have to have worked with it for
years to jump in and do this one.

47
00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:24.460
So if you've never used
Project even a single time,

48
00:02:24.460 --> 00:02:26.550
well we're gonna start out
right there at that beginning.

49
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:30.070
Opening the program, creating that first
project, and getting moving forward, so

50
00:02:30.070 --> 00:02:31.600
really, really useful stuff.

51
00:02:31.600 --> 00:02:33.250
And for the rest of the objectives,

52
00:02:33.250 --> 00:02:38.270
Microsoft really stayed true to the stuff
you're really gonna use type topics.

53
00:02:38.270 --> 00:02:41.890
Not the esoteric, weird features that
most people don't work with, but

54
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:46.192
the features that are really important to
everybody who serves as a project manager

55
00:02:46.192 --> 00:02:48.930
or just works within
a project environment.

56
00:02:48.930 --> 00:02:54.190
So, for example, the very second
objective is well, scheduling, right?

57
00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:58.780
Which is really important, it's a key
piece of what a project manager does for

58
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:03.310
a living, but it's also important for
anybody who participates in that project.

59
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:06.280
A project is broken up
into multiple tasks.

60
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:09.850
And how do we make sure those tasks are
occurring on time, you know at completion?

61
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:12.860
How do we know if we're getting behind
schedule or if we're ahead of schedule?

62
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:15.380
We need to be able to understand that and
Microsoft Project can help us do that.

63
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:20.170
>> All right, it's a great place for us to
at least get all of the tasks that we have

64
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:22.190
ready to go and put it in one place.

65
00:03:22.190 --> 00:03:23.610
Then that way we can see it.

66
00:03:23.610 --> 00:03:26.070
And we'll end up seeing that once
we talk about creating a basic,

67
00:03:27.160 --> 00:03:29.570
a task based schedule.

68
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:31.870
We'll then be able to
start manipulating it and

69
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:35.020
changing it into the information
that we really need.

70
00:03:35.020 --> 00:03:38.490
So they go into simple things like setting
up some basic information that we need for

71
00:03:38.490 --> 00:03:40.250
the overall project, and

72
00:03:40.250 --> 00:03:42.520
even setting up what we'll call
the project task structure, and

73
00:03:42.520 --> 00:03:46.560
then logically structuring everything
the way that it needs to be done.

74
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:49.080
The nice thing about Project is you
can just throw stuff in it, and

75
00:03:49.080 --> 00:03:52.460
then later on work with it and massage it
into what you actually would like to see.

76
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:57.190
>> Yeah, now, the third objective
is our resource management.

77
00:03:57.190 --> 00:03:58.940
Once you've created all these tasks,

78
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:01.100
somebody has to actually do the work,
right?

79
00:04:01.100 --> 00:04:05.000
So we need to assign people to the tasks
to do it, or maybe it's not people.

80
00:04:05.000 --> 00:04:07.770
Maybe it's equipment,
machinery, other things,

81
00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:09.662
other resources that we have to manage.

82
00:04:09.662 --> 00:04:12.970
We need to keep track of that to make
sure that we don't do any kind of

83
00:04:12.970 --> 00:04:14.210
over allocation.

84
00:04:14.210 --> 00:04:17.870
I don't want to book Ronnie to
do two things at the same time.

85
00:04:17.870 --> 00:04:21.790
So we gotta make sure that we can have
that in an easy to see environment,

86
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:24.530
that helps us to locate area's
where we've got problems.

87
00:04:24.530 --> 00:04:26.620
Where we don't have enough resources, or

88
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:29.440
we've over allocated somebody and
created an issue.

89
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:32.630
So, that's what the third
objective is all about.

90
00:04:32.630 --> 00:04:35.960
As we scroll down I can see that
the fourth objective takes a look at

91
00:04:35.960 --> 00:04:38.880
tracking and analyzing a project itself.

92
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:42.480
Once we get everything in place inside
the project, we know actually start seeing

93
00:04:42.480 --> 00:04:45.920
the power of Microsoft project
to display what we need to.

94
00:04:45.920 --> 00:04:49.190
So that what we can do is we can
take the information out of Project,

95
00:04:49.190 --> 00:04:52.590
be able to create the reports that we
need, be able to analyze the information,

96
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:55.540
and that way keep our project on
schedule in the way that it needs to go.

97
00:04:55.540 --> 00:05:01.130
>> Now the fifth objective, and the final
objective, is probably my favorite because

98
00:05:01.130 --> 00:05:03.960
all this good information inside of
Microsoft Project is all designed for

99
00:05:03.960 --> 00:05:05.050
project managers.

100
00:05:05.050 --> 00:05:07.690
Microsoft knows that it's project
managers that are gonna be using this

101
00:05:07.690 --> 00:05:08.780
software the most.

102
00:05:08.780 --> 00:05:11.540
And so the terminology that's used,
the tools,

103
00:05:11.540 --> 00:05:14.880
it's all built around what
we do as a project manager.

104
00:05:14.880 --> 00:05:19.700
But the rest of your company needs to be
able to benefit from this information, and

105
00:05:19.700 --> 00:05:21.870
they don't know what a BCWP is.

106
00:05:21.870 --> 00:05:24.290
They don't understand planned value or
an SPI.

107
00:05:24.290 --> 00:05:26.240
That stuff doesn't mean anything to them.

108
00:05:26.240 --> 00:05:29.880
So we've gotta have some way to
take the information in project and

109
00:05:29.880 --> 00:05:35.410
get that out in a way that's meaningful to
the other people in our company, right?

110
00:05:35.410 --> 00:05:38.950
If I give somebody a calendar,
they know what a calendar is.

111
00:05:38.950 --> 00:05:39.570
They can read that.

112
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:42.300
They go, this is Tuesday,
I'm supposed to be here at this time.

113
00:05:42.300 --> 00:05:43.770
They understand that, right?

114
00:05:43.770 --> 00:05:48.290
Or here's a pie chart that shows tasks
that are completed, and tasks that aren't.

115
00:05:48.290 --> 00:05:50.360
That's the kind of information
people understand.

116
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:54.260
And Project has a ton of
ways to output data and

117
00:05:54.260 --> 00:05:59.860
translate it from our project management
language into regular English,

118
00:05:59.860 --> 00:06:02.620
or well whatever language
you speak in your country.

119
00:06:02.620 --> 00:06:05.250
Into regular easily understandable charts,

120
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:09.040
diagrams, lists,
just all sorts of different formats.

121
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:10.410
It's really powerful.

122
00:06:10.410 --> 00:06:10.910
>> It really is.

123
00:06:10.910 --> 00:06:14.650
So, those are the five objectives that
we're taking a look at when we go through

124
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:20.600
our show here, for the 74-343 show, and
there's a lot for us to cover, Don.

125
00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:24.240
>> Yeah, so if that sounds exciting and
fun to you you're in the right place.

126
00:06:24.240 --> 00:06:25.590
Stay tuned for it.

127
00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:30.240
Also keep in mind that this is
using a tool to manage projects.

128
00:06:30.240 --> 00:06:33.830
If you want to learn more about
actually doing project management,

129
00:06:33.830 --> 00:06:37.470
just the concepts and theory behind it,
we do have other training here on ITProTV

130
00:06:37.470 --> 00:06:40.310
like the project management
professional training that we did.

131
00:06:40.310 --> 00:06:41.500
So check that out, too.

132
00:06:41.500 --> 00:06:43.650
Now, the order doesn't really matter.

133
00:06:43.650 --> 00:06:46.470
You can learn the tool first and
then learn the fundamentals later, or

134
00:06:46.470 --> 00:06:47.210
the other way around.

135
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:50.970
But I find it is pretty beneficial to
already understand the fundamentals,

136
00:06:50.970 --> 00:06:55.270
if we're doing task scheduling, you should
probably understand the concepts behind

137
00:06:55.270 --> 00:06:57.620
duration, resource allocation, and so on.

138
00:06:57.620 --> 00:06:58.940
So if you haven't already,

139
00:06:58.940 --> 00:07:01.530
be sure to check out the project
management professionals series.

140
00:07:01.530 --> 00:07:02.880
It's a great one.

141
00:07:02.880 --> 00:07:04.060
It was you and I Ronnie, right?

142
00:07:04.060 --> 00:07:06.959
We did that one.
So, [LAUGH] filmed it a few months ago.

143
00:07:06.959 --> 00:07:08.918
So definitely it's something
worth checking out.

144
00:07:08.918 --> 00:07:11.583
But as far as Microsoft Project,
this is the place to be.

145
00:07:11.583 --> 00:07:14.876
So stay tuned,
we got Microsoft Project coming up next.

146
00:07:14.876 --> 00:07:20.125
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don guide through getting started with Microsoft Project 2013.  They show some of the ways that Project allows a user to get started right way using Project by creating templates, using templates, and creating a project plan from other applications.
episodes.title: Create a New Project

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don demonstrate one of the most powerful features in Project, custom fields.  Custom fields allow us to show customized data.  Instead of displaying only the default fields, we can use tools provided in Project to allow us to display a calculated field, a lookup field or even just a string field that we would like to see that project didn't specifically create by default.
episodes.title: Custom Fields

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don walk through some of the different customization to change default settings within project. This customization done before the project plan has progressed much will help speed up the process and make items display the way you want rather than the default settings.
episodes.title: Settings Options

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don setup one of the most important options to get right from the beginning which is to establish the project start date.  The explore the options found within the Project Information dialog box and explain the importance of each setting.
episodes.title: Set Up Project Information

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into creating tasks manually within a project plan.  They also show how you can rearrange the tasks within a project plan, create milestones and set a task as active or inactive to do show "What if" scenarios easily.  They complete the show by adding a recurring task to our plan.
episodes.title: Creating Tasks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss and demonstrate some of the different ways to control the project schedule using date constraints and dependencies and show how to link task together so that Project 2013 can use it's scheduling engine to put things in proper order. Understanding where and when to use the constraints in Project 2013 is an important part of working with the software.
episodes.title: Task Relationships

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the math and calculation of work, duration and resources that Microsoft Project 2013 works in the background.  They talk about the differences between effort-driven and non-effort driven tasks. The show where to set the task types as well as how to view how the formulas work out using the details view.
episodes.title: Task Relationships Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don guide us through creating a manually controlled scheduled.  This type of scheduling will give the user the most direct control over each task and resource.  They show how it can affect a auto-scheduled plan as well how to do PERT analysis to manually estimate task durations.
episodes.title: Creating a Schedule

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at how to work with multiple related projects using a single pool of resources. Project 2013 provides the ability to create Master Project Plans and to link those projects together so that we can see how they affect the schedule.  They also show now multiple projects can connect and use a shared resource pools.
episodes.title: Managing Multiple Projects

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don show us how to add resources to a project plan.  It's not enough just to list the resources but a user should be able to different resources and the data associated with the resource so it can be tracked by Project. They talk about all the fields associated with resources and show how the resources can be created in the project plan.
episodes.title: Resource Information

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Ronnie dive into assigning resources to tasks.  It is this action that connects tasks and resource together to see how the project engine starts to change the schedule.  It's important for the project manager to know not only how to assign a resource but how to change a resource and even change the availability.
episodes.title: Resource Assignments

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into one of the most useful views that shows resources and allocation.  This view, the Team Planner, allows you also to manipulate the resources visually and easily see resource conflicts and overallocations.  From the Team planner, you can also manually level resources too.  It's a great view for the project manager to know.
episodes.title: Team Planner

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to model the project cost of a project plan.  A project plan is nearing nearing completion for execution when you can see not only what needs to be done and who is going to do it but when you have at least a knowledge of what the cost of the project is projected to be. Knowing how to enter cost to a plan is essential to that. They show how to center cost and have it show up for a baseline cost model.
episodes.title: Model Project Costs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to model the material resource cost of a project plan.  Materials are normally resources we use up, consume, during our project.  We have materials that are used up over time and other material that we may cost us all at one time. The guys show how to account for both possible types of material resource modeling.
episodes.title: Model Material Resource Costs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie introduces to using baselines within our project plan.  Baselines allow us to create a snaphot of project start and finish dates, work, cost and duration data. This will allow us to track the progress of our plan without losing track of the original project plan data.  Then a Project manager can compare against to baseline to measure whether the current project is on schedule, on budget and on goal or not by using baselines.
episodes.title: Setting Baselines

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie shows how to begin to update progress within a project plan.  He shows multiple ways that task progress can be recorded.  Also discussed is how to reschedule uncompleted task.
episodes.title: Update Progress

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie talks about he need to track variance within the Project Plan.  Once a baseline is stored, you begin to track progress and variance is created.  Changes to the plan not only needs to be updated but seed a variance to the original plan.  Here we see the date, work an cost variance so that good decisions can be made to keep the project on schedule.
episodes.title: Baseline Variances

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie demonstrates some of the tools that are built into Microsoft Project 2013 that alerts, identifies and even helps when scheduling issues appear.  Though these are built it, you may find them doing more than you want. So we also see the manual way to deal with overallocations.
episodes.title: Resolve Schedule Issues

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie take a look at displaying critical path information. The critical path is the string of tasks linked together in which every task must finish on schedule if the project is to finish on schedule.  Displaying this can help a project manager to see where to best apply resources and see all the tasks he must manage if he is to have the scheduled finish date.
episodes.title: Display Critical Path

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don walk through the options to customize how Project 2013 will project data.  They show the simple filtering options and show some of the data display options for highlighting and grouping too.  They also show how you can reuse project information by using the organizer to share specific items between different project plans.
episodes.title: Applying Custom Views

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at getting Project data available in other applications besides Project. Project 2013 has made it easier to make the project information available beyond the application itself.
episodes.title: Sharing Project Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss the power of Projects Reporting tools.  Microsoft Project makes it fairly intuitive to create presentation ready reports by default.  They provide the most common reports likely needed and give you the ability to create custom reports when the default options are not what you need.
episodes.title: Reports and Dashboards

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don talk about and show some of the different way to make Project 2013 extend it's capabilities by using applications, saving to one drive and using VBA to complete repeating tasks. These option make project a very extensible tool to apply it any project you choose to manage.
episodes.title: Project Extensions
